00004 #include "irrlicht.h"

00006 #include "Common.h"

00009 #include "LevelManager.h"
00010 #include "Level.h"
00011 #include "WorldEntity.h"
00012 #include <stdio.h>
00013 
00014 /* 
00015 There are 5 sub namespaces in the Irrlicht Engine. Take a look 
00016 at them, you can read a detailed description of them in the 
00017 documentation by clicking on the top menu item 'Namespace List'
00018 or using this link: http://irrlicht.sourceforge.net/docu/namespaces.html.
00019 Like the irr Namespace, we do not want these 5 sub namespaces now,
00020 to keep this example simple. Hence we tell the compiler again
00021 that we do not want always to write their names:
00022 */
00023 using namespace irr::core;
00024 using namespace irr::scene;
00025 using namespace irr::video;
00026 using namespace irr::gui;
00027 
00028 
00029 irr::scene::ISceneManager* smgr;
00030 irr::IrrlichtDevice *device;
00031 
00032 bool init(){
00033         InputManager::getSingleton().init();
00034         device = irr::createDevice( irr::video::EDT_DIRECT3D9, irr::core::dimension2d<irr::s32>(800, 600), 16,
00035                 false, false, false, InputManager::getSingleton().getEventReceiver());
00036 
00037         smgr = device->getSceneManager();
00038 
00039         LevelManager::getSingleton().init(device, "./res/scenarios/tutorial.xml");
00040 
00041         LevelManager::getSingleton().startGame();
00042 
00043         return true;
00044 }
00045 
00046 /*
00047 This is the main method. We can use int main() on every platform.
00048 On Windows platforms, we could also use the WinMain method
00049 if we would want to get rid of the console window, which pops up when
00050 starting a program with main(), but to keep this example simple,
00051 we use main().
00052 */
00053 int main()
00054 {
00055         init();
00056 
00057         /*
00058         Set the caption of the window to some nice text. Note that there is 
00059         a 'L' in front of the string. The Irrlicht Engine uses wide character
00060         strings when displaying text.
00061         */
00062         device->setWindowCaption(L"Hello World! - Irrlicht Engine Demo");
00063 
00064         /*
00065         Get a pointer to the video driver, the SceneManager and the
00066         graphical user interface environment, so that
00067         we do not always have to write device->getVideoDriver(),
00068         device->getSceneManager() and device->getGUIEnvironment().
00069         */
00070         IVideoDriver* driver = device->getVideoDriver();
00071         IGUIEnvironment* guienv = device->getGUIEnvironment();
00072 
00073         /*
00074         We add a hello world label to the window, using the GUI environment.
00075         */
00076         
00077         guienv->addStaticText(L"Hello World! This is the Irrlicht Software renderer!",
00078                 rect<irr::s32>(10,10,260,22), true);
00079 
00080         /*
00081         To display something interesting, we load a Quake 2 model 
00082         and display it. We only have to get the Mesh from the Scene 
00083         Manager (getMesh()) and add a SceneNode to display the mesh.
00084         (addAnimatedMeshSceneNode()). Instead of writing the filename
00085         sydney.md2, it would also be possible to load a Maya object file
00086         (.obj), a complete Quake3 map (.bsp) or a Milshape file (.ms3d).
00087         By the way, that cool Quake 2 model called sydney was modelled
00088         by Brian Collins.
00089         */
00090 
00091 
00092         /*
00093         To let the mesh look a little bit nicer, we change its material a
00094         little bit: We disable lighting because we do not have a dynamic light
00095         in here, and the mesh would be totally black. Then we set the frame
00096         loop, so that the animation is looped between the frames 0 and 310.
00097         And at last, we apply a texture to the mesh. Without it the mesh
00098         would be drawn using only a color.
00099         */
00100 
00101 
00102         /*
00103         To look at the mesh, we place a camera into 3d space at the position
00104         (0, 30, -40). The camera looks from there to (0,5,0).
00105         */
00106         smgr->addCameraSceneNode(0, irr::core::vector3df(0,100,-240), irr::core::vector3df(10,100,0));
00107 
00108 
00109         //Makes the mouse invisible
00110         device->getCursorControl()->setVisible(false);
00111         /*
00112         Ok, now we have set up the scene, lets draw everything:
00113         We run the device in a while() loop, until the device does not
00114         want to run any more. This would be when the user closed the window
00115         or pressed ALT+F4 in windows.
00116         */
00117 
00118         bool show = false;
00119         while(device->run())
00120         {
00121                 /*
00122                 Anything can be drawn between a beginScene() and an endScene()
00123                 call. The beginScene clears the screen with a color and also the
00124                 depth buffer if wanted. Then we let the Scene Manager and the
00125                 GUI Environment draw their content. With the endScene() call
00126                 everything is presented on the screen.
00127                 */
00128                 InputManager::getSingleton().stopPolling();
00129                 InputManager::getSingleton().getInput();
00130                 LevelManager::getSingleton().update();
00131                 driver->beginScene(true, true, SColor(255,100,101,140));
00132                         smgr->drawAll();
00133                         guienv->drawAll();
00134                 driver->endScene();
00135 
00136                 InputManager::getSingleton().resumePolling();
00137         }
00138 
00139         /*
00140         After we are finished, we have to delete the Irrlicht Device
00141         created before with createDevice(). In the Irrlicht Engine, 
00142         you will have to delete all objects you created with a method or 
00143         function which starts with 'create'. The object is simply deleted
00144         by calling ->drop().
00145         See the documentation at 
00146         http://irrlicht.sourceforge.net//docu/classirr_1_1IUnknown.html#a3
00147         for more information.
00148         */
00149         InputManager::getSingleton().shutdown();
00150         LevelManager::getSingleton().shutdown();
00151         device->drop();
00152 
00153         return 0;
00154 }
